clues.text: The name of this order of mammals comes from the Latin verb "robere", meaning to gnaw
Despite its name, this largest dolphin, Orcinus orca, normally doesn't attack humans
The giant species of this "armor-plated" animal   has more teeth than any other land mammal
The African & Sumatran species of this animal have 2 horns; the Indian & Javan species have 1
Once abundant, now protected, it the heaviest land mammal native to North America
Oxford 1st admitted these people in the late 1800s, but they couldn't earn degrees until 1920
This late Welsh actor won a scholarship to Oxford before winning Liz's hand
This founder of Pennsylvania was expelled from Oxford in 1661, which must have made him "quake"
He went to Oxford on an organ scholarship long before he starred in "10"
This playwright knew "the importance of" going to Oxford: he graduated with honors in 1878

My God!
Great prize
Literally, white card
That's life

In December 2019 her "All I Want For Christmas Is You" completed the longest trip from release to Billboard No. 1: 25 years
Real name Austin Post, he has been running "Circles" around the competition
Complemented by its lush video, "Rare" from this former TV wizard was a singular hit in the new decade
In her cover of "Doin' Time", she reimagines Gershwin & Sublime
From "Treasure Island" comes the refrain "Fifteen men on the dead man's chest, yo-ho-ho" & one of these
These sailor songs helped pass time during strenuous labor, like the halyard type sung when hoisting sails
"They send you to New Bedford" in "Blow Ye Winds", a song about this maritime activity
Captain Quint in "Jaws" sang the lament, "Farewell, and adieu to" these women
"A drop of Nelson's blood won't do us any harm"; "Nelson" referring to Admiral Horatio & "blood" being this 4-letter potent potable
Born 1890, was a merchant of "murder" & "death", named a dame in 1971, & then there was none of her in 1976
Born 1898, taught at Oxford & Cambridge, chronicled big cats, enchantresses & closets, died 1963
Born 1919, came through the rye to fame in 1951, & we're not too sure what he did from 1965 to his death in 2010
Born in 1903 with the initials E.A.B., took his pen name from an English river in 1933, passed away in 1950, 34 years early
Born 1709 in England, wrote a dictionary, got bio'd, buried in Westminster Abbey in 1784
In this country ha-matzav, "the situation", refers to the security threats it has faced since the day of independence in 1948
Zero-sum is an alternative to this happier type of double-talk situation
In 1950 he spoke about the situation in Korea: "A small country, thousands of miles away, but...important to every American"
Churchill's June 4, 1940 speech on the war situation narrates this evacuation of 335,000 troops from the shores of France
Demosthenes spent years convincing Athenians they were in a crisis situation due to the threat from this dad of Alexander
In 2019, using the Event Horizon Telescope, the first of these cosmic objects was photographed
A study at Johns Hopkins suggests that being around dogs at an early age may lessen the risk of this "split mind" disorder
Observed in 2019, 2I/Borisov is the first identified one of these bodies of rock & ice to visit from outside our solar system
RBBP6, one of these compounds that contain amino acids, has proven effective against Ebola
Developers of this hyphenated type of battery that powers smartphones & electric cars won the 2019 Nobel Chemistry Prize
Change a letter in the color of money into the rapacious desire for said money
A word meaning mild or not very flavorful spices things up by becoming a verb meaning to mix
With a change of just one letter, to burn slightly becomes a single-named superstar singer/actress
A word meaning of short duration turns very sad as one denoting sharp sorrow over a death
Change a letter in the opposite of illuminated to get a word for unpleasantly damp & chilly

Doctoral students write dissertations; a master's degree usually requires one of these, from the Greek for "proposition"
We'll gamble you know that this word for an exam supervisor once meant a Roman governor
An experienced teacher who helps guide a new teacher; also, the name of a guide in the "Odyssey"
This synonym of proficiency describes a type of learning that allows students to progress at the rate at which they master skills

He's been king of Sweden since 1973 & XVI properly comes between Carl & this name

rounds.text: The stars on this country's flag represent states, 26 of them; unlike the USA's, its "federal district" gets its own 27th star
